The Civics Center is dedicated to building the foundations of youth civic engagement and voter participation in high schools through education, organizing, and advocacy.

In Maine, you can preregister to vote at age 16 so long as you are a US citizen and have an established home in Maine. To vote in a Referendum or General Election, you must be registered in the community where you live, and be at least 18 years of age. A 17 year old may vote in a Primary Election, if that person will be 18 by the General Election.

Interested? Follow this link to register or preregister to vote - https://thecivicscenter.org/register.

Last night the RSU 9 Board of Directors voted to approve the Return to School Models as proposed by district administration on August 11. Due to the continued struggle to maintain social distance for students while transporting by bus, the administration proposed a revised Hybrid Model for Grades PreK-8, changing it to a cohort based Blue/Gold alternate day two-week schedule as illustrated below.

RSU 9 Athletic Fields Partially Open

Athletic fields across Mt. Blue Regional School District are now open for individual use and independent activities like: walking or running on the track; riding a bike; tossing a football, frisbee, lacrosse ball; batting or tossing a baseball; flying a kite; or playing tennis.

The partial reopening does NOT include: organized or group sports; or league or sport specific games or training events.

The health and safety of RSU 9 community members is crucial as the district focuses and plans to reopen schools in the fall. Therefore, those enjoying the facilities are expected to follow national and state CDC recommendations by maintaining a six-foot social distance from those not in your household and wearing a face covering if/when others are present. The district reserves the right to deny access to those not complying with the use expectations.

Today’s students are dealing with stresses and pressures very different from those of prior generations. Parents, teachers and school administrators are too, and that was before COVID-19 arrived and disrupted our everyday lives and routines.

In an effort to help all of us adjust to the “new normal,” Dartmouth-Hitchcock has created a virtual mental health series, available on multiple interactive platforms, beginning Wednesday, April 22. It will offer helpful, practical advice to students, parents, grandparents, seniors and others who are confronting the new, everyday challenges the virus has created.

Dartmouth-Hitchcock has assembled knowledgeable teams of experts for this timely six-week series that will be broadcast every Wednesday at noon, April 22 through May 27. Follow the link below for more details. There is no cost to watch and participate in the series.

The links to each webinar are shared on D-H’s Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram accounts prior to each live event. Additionally, each webinar is archived on the D-H Facebook page and YouTube channel.

Our music department is having an impact even though lessons are being done remotely. They have adopted a mindset that music can help provide a sense of joy, connection, and community during this unusual time. They are taking advantage of this opportunity to help students explore music in a way that is not always possible in the classroom.

6-12 teachers have posted state and national music opportunities, such as a Live Stream Sing-Along with Broadway Cast of "Hamilton," online master classes with top instrumentalists, and Maine Virtual Choir.

Most students have their instruments at home at this time so this is a great time to practice, practice, practice! #learningisfun; #rsu9proud

The members of the RSU 9 science department are having students continue with experiential science education at home. They are doing this in a wide variety of ways, including using homemade demonstration videos, on-line photo presentations, having students make observations, collect data, and make connections in their local outdoor environment. They are also engaging in many Zoom discussion sessions, continued field research, virtual field trips, examining virus “ecology,” the construction of personal rock collections, and some really creative kitchen chemistry experiments! #rsu9proud #learningisfun

FOOD SERVICE UPDATE

March 30, 2020

Good afternoon RSU 9 Community,

As you can imagine, the RSU 9 School Nutrition Program is operating at full speed. Since March 17, the second day of our district wide school closure, RSU 9’s school nutrition and other staff have prepared and packaged close to 15,000 breakfast and lunch meals for pick-up, drop-off, and door-to-door delivery by volunteer drivers to those who can’t make it to a pick-up location.

Due to the extremely high number of meals produced and distributed each day, last Friday’s delivery included the final weekend extra meal delivery we are able to provide. If necessary, we encourage you to use other community resources to fulfill your weekend needs.

It is important to note that the funding for these meals comes primarily from the USDA Child Nutrition Program which is for children, birth to age 19 only. Meals should not be ordered or picked up for adults. Your cooperation will help to ensure we can continue to serve meals to the children of our communities.

Warm Regards,

Tina Meserve
Superintendent of Schools

Betsy Brady received praise from Maine DOE Commissioner Pender Makin for her work on the review of the standards for Career and Education Development.

Betsy served on the Steering Committee charged with reviewing the Maine Learning Results standards for Career and Education Development. The Committee spent three days reviewing public comments, state statutes, current standards, and research on career development and social emotional development before creating a guidance document articulating the degree of revision for the standards. A Writing Team used their guidance and was able to revise the standards which are currently on target to be considered by the 129th Legislature.

Commissioner Makin touted their work by saying, "The Steering Committee deserves huge kudos for the work and should be very proud of their part in advancing career education in Maine".

Thank you Betsy for going above and beyond for Maine's career and technical education students! #rsu9proud
